text: Hop into Rust's science and AI chatroom and see love for JuliaLang. What a nice thing :)

elements.text: Hop into Rust's science and AI chatroom and see love for JuliaLang. What a nice thing :)

text: I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected

elements.text: I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected

text: Yea I think the idea is, Julia is amazing for mathy stuff, Rust is pretty awesome for systemsy stuff. If you need mathy systemsy stuff, it makes sense to use both :slightly_smiling_face:. But I agree very different end use for the tools.

elements.text: Yea I think the idea is, Julia is amazing for mathy stuff, Rust is pretty awesome for systemsy stuff. If you need mathy systemsy stuff, it makes sense to use both
. But I agree very different end use for the tools.

text:
> I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected
presumably this is exactly why they have good things to say about Julia. Overlapping domains leads to combative attitudes

elements.text: I'm actually impressed, I didn't expect too much interest in Julia in the rust community, as the domains are somewhat disconnected
presumably this is exactly why they have good things to say about Julia. Overlapping domains leads to combative attitudes

text: Presumably, these users wouldn’t see a success for Julia as a loss for Rust.

elements.text: Presumably, these users wouldn’t see a success for Julia as a loss for Rust.

text: One of the things that I think would massively help both languages is if we could get more people bringing knowledge back and forth. Some sort of convention for open source language writing would be great. I'm sure there are a ton of really cool techniques that could be broadly applicable, but are currently siloed knowledge to 1 comunity

elements.text: One of the things that I think would massively help both languages is if we could get more people bringing knowledge back and forth. Some sort of convention for open source language writing would be great. I'm sure there are a ton of really cool techniques that could be broadly applicable, but are currently siloed knowledge to 1 comunity

text: I’ve been interested in Rust (and now Zig) for making low-level libraries (where there is no need for being able to use different types) that can be easily used via ccall from Julia.   It’s a step up from using C libraries :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I’ve been interested in Rust (and now Zig) for making low-level libraries (where there is no need for being able to use different types) that can be easily used via ccall from Julia.   It’s a step up from using C libraries

text:
Does mathy + systemy stuff even exist?
Those are really two different domains.....

elements.text:
Does mathy + systemy stuff even exist?

text: drone control is one example

text: But again, I see that when someone wants to write maths stuff "for production", they mostly turn to Rust, C, Cpp, (or other compiled languages) etc

text: I hear that Rust is really not suited by design, for IOT

elements.text: I hear that Rust is really not suited by design, for IOT

text: but yea, it's really common to take code code written in a scripting language and toss it into a statically compiled something or another. People don't do it for fun. Typically you get better performance, less overhead, and better options for I/O

elements.text: but yea, it's really common to take code code written in a scripting language and toss it into a statically compiled something or another. People don't do it for fun. Typically you get better performance, less overhead, and better options for I/O

text: Of course, people are doing IoT stuff in Rust, but then I think its just not that suited for it.....

elements.text: Of course, people are doing IoT stuff in Rust, but then I think its just not that suited for it.....

text: my understanding is Rust does just fine for IoT devices, but I mean, most people probably run to C or something

text: pick the right tool for the job I guess lol, but yea Rust doesn't solve all problems

We'll get a working StaticCompiler.jl in due time...:eyes:
Then they might not run to some other language

text: Rust does too many things like implicit allocations and overreaching safety checks, you do not get the control needed for embedded

text: the stacks are developed for embedded, but the semantics of the language still do not work for a wide variety of embedded usecases

text: I don't do enough embedded work to really hyper focus on a lot of things. I mostly focus on like how do I run this algorithm as lean as possible on a tiny brain. The I/O yadda yadda is not typically in my hands. I mean, sometimes I do some infrastructure on the outside of some embedded system but it's not something I'm "good at".

text:
> Yea no Zig for me until that puppy hits 1.0
I just hope I don't have any need of a C-like language before Zig's stage2 compiler comes out!:smiling_face_with_tear:
I _really_ like its syntax....

Also, Zig builder offers an escape from the hell that is cmake

text: Everyone says Zig is great, but, if someone wants something written in C - from me, well first I am going to remind them that "this really isn't what I do", after they ignore all that and restate the deadline, I am definitely not gonna turn over something in an obscure language instead.

elements.text: Everyone says Zig is great, but, if someone wants something written in C - from me, well first I am going to remind them that "this really isn't what I do", after they ignore all that and restate the deadline, I am definitely not gonna turn over something in an obscure language instead.

text:
As for myself, I haven't entered the world of embedded yet (I think I will, right after I graduate from my undergrad program)
I hope Zig develops until then!

text:
I don't really use anything other than Julia for important stuff/experimentation/learning
Although I love playing with new languages, right now that'd be Zig and Janet, I don't think I'd create anything important with them for now.....

Carp seems nice, but Janet is actually the first language I saw run on wasm on a website
<https://janet-lang.org/>
(julia-wasm is still incomplete)

attachments.title: The Janet Programming Language
attachments.text: Janet is a functional and imperative programming language. It runs on Windows, Linux, macOS, FreeBSD and *nix.
